Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Advanced Ion Channel Models for Neurological Signal Processing -- Theory and Application to Brain-Computer Interfacing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators are studying the scientific theory and engineering consequences of the electrical noise signals generated by neurons inside the brain. They are developing a deeper understanding of this neuronal noise primarily to improve brain-computer interfaces (BCIs), which enhance the quality of life of patients with various paralyzing disabilities such as Lou Gehrig?s disease. By understanding the statistical characteristics of the background noise, they are able to reduce its interference with the conscious signal generated by the brain of the paralyzed patient. This creates a much more reliable control signal for wheelchairs, customized internet browsers, and the home environment. In addition, the investigators are applying their advanced neuron models to gain insight into non-diseased brain tissue and the processes by which it creates and transmits information. This promises to have significant implications for understanding the functioning of both natural and synthetic neural networks.

Specifically, the investigators have developed a novel mathematical and stochastic model for neuronal ion channels that takes into account quantum mechanical and thermodynamic considerations. The principle of entropy maximization applied to a population of these quantum ion channels in thermal equilibrium explains the ubiquitous presence of the so-called 1/f-noise in neural and electroencephalographic (EEG) recordings. The parameters derived from these models are combined with a new signal processing paradigm called octave-averaged spectral rectification to dramatically reduce the interfering effect of 1/f-noise on EEG signals. As a result, the stimulus frequencies of an experimental type of brain interface called steady-state visual evoked potential (SSVEP) BCIs can be increased into the high-gamma band above 30Hz. This dramatically reduces the negative side effects of these SSVEP BCIs and makes them of practical use for the first time to paralyzed patients as well as heads-up displays for pilots and surgeons, and high-performance game control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project is to develop biophysically-consistent mathematical and stochastic models that can explain and identify the origin of 1/f-type neuronal noise observed in neurological membranes. The second goal is to leverage these insights to inform the design of efficient algorithms for EEG-based brain-computer-interfaces (BCI) that connect the human central nervous system to electronic and mechanical devices. Advancing such BCIs holds immense potential to improve the quality of life of patients suffering from motor paralysis due to neurological disorders and to realize situational awareness in battlefields.

Regarding the first goal, a significant achievement of this project was our development of the theory and application of a new family of EEG noise processes we call generalized Van der Ziel-McWhorter noise (GVZM) which have relatively few parameters and whose power spectral densities match recorded EEG spectra with high accuracy. Another notable contribution of this project is the development of a plausible neurophysical quantum-based mechanism by which channel and membrane kinetics can provably give rise to GVZM noise spectra. 

The brain's response to repetitive visual stimuli, known as the Steady State Visual Evoked Potentials (SSVEPs), exhibit periodicity patterns similar to those of the external stimuli. However, teasing out useful information from such signals is a formidably challenging task considering the very low SNR of non-invasive EEG. On the algorithmic front, this project contributed real-time estimation algorithms for SSVEP frequencies based on the GVZM models that demonstrate significant accuracy improvement over state-of-the-art SSVEP estimators. Our research also led to the development of transformative and powerful algorithms for detecting periodicities in EEG data based on representations in Ramanujan Periodicity Transform (RPT) dictionaries. The ability of such detectors to maintain high levels of accuracy with very short data epochs and their robustness to natural latencies associated with the brain's response to external stimuli make them very appealing for emerging real-time BCI.   

The results of this project have been published in top journal and conference papers, including the MIT Press Neural Computation Journal, the IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering, and the Neural Engineering Journal. The activities of this project also imparted training at the graduate and undergraduate levels and contributed to the professional development of a postdoctoral researcher. Two undergraduates were involved in the development and implementation of an SSVEP-based BCI control system for a power chair. 

The deeper understanding of the statistical characteristics of the background noise afforded by the new noise models along with the fresh signal processing paradigms developed hold potential to dramatically reduce the interfering effect of 1/f-noise on EEG signals. This could potentially enable high-frequency gamma-band SSVEP BCIs with reduced negative side effects making them of practical use to paralyzed patients, heads-up displays for pilots and surgeons, and high-performance game control. Improving our ability to probe the brain offers an important avenue for advancing our understanding of, and competence to treat, devastating brain disorders such as epilepsy and Alzheimer's disease which pose huge human and economic burden on our country and the world.
